photos.author: © David Blank (Creative Commons Attribution-Noncommercial-Share Alike 3.0 Unported License)

invasion: native to Southeast Asia
introduced as a pet
can cause severe debarking of trees
can outcompete native squirrels for food and nest sites
behavior: herbivorous species, consumes leaves, flowers, fruits, seeds
commonly found in tree hollows
constructs leaf nests above the ground
young individuals disperse from their natal areas and establish their own home ranges
habitat: broadleaved and conifer forests
city parks
confusion: distinction from other squirrels can be difficult
can be distinguished by the absence of black and buff stripes along the flanks
appearance: a medium-sized tree squirrel, up to 50 cm long (including the tail)
usually brownish on the upper body, reddish on the belly, often some black on the tail
coloration can vary depending on geography

photos.author: © Krister Brandser (public domain)
© Krister Brandser (public domain)
© Krister Brandser (public domain)

invasion: native to Middle East, probably Iran
introduced as an ornamental plant
can outcompete native plants and become a plague
its bristles can cause eczema after physical contact; after exposure sunlight should be avoided
the seeds are used in Persian cooking
behavior: perennial species
prefers moist and nutritious soils
flowers during summer
habitat: terrestrial, common in gardens, parks and near urban areas
confusion: easily confused with other Heracleum species (such as H. mantegazzianum)
can be distinguished by the color of the stems’ base and the shape of the leaflets’ lobes
appearance: herb, up to 1.5 m high
many stems, bristly haired, red-brown in their base
leaves alternate, stalked, pinnate in 5 segments, with lower side haired, glabrous on top
leaflets lobed, with blunt-toothed margins
flowers white, forming a compound umbel
small seeds, obovate, 8 mm long

photos.author: Grey Squirrel - GBNNSS  © Crown Copyright 2009
Photo from www.nobanis.org, photographer: Merike Linnämagi
Photo from www.nobanis.org, photographer: Merike Linnämagi
Grey Squirrel - GBNNSS  © Crown Copyright 2009

invasion: native in the USA
introduced as a pet
can damage trees by stripping the bark, exposing them to fungi and insects
may cause local extinction of the red squirrel through competition and diseases
behavior: spends most of its time on the ground
feeds on nuts, flowers, buds, fruits, fungi, some insects, bird eggs
pilfers the caches of red squirrels
habitat: broadleaf woodlands and conifer forests
urban parks
confusion: None
appearance: a medium-sized tree squirrel up to 50 cm long including tail
back grizzled dark to pale grey
hips, feet and head olive brown
tail white to pale grey

photos.author: Curly Waterweed - © RPS group Plc
Curly Waterweed - © RPS group Plc

invasion: native to South Tropical Africa
introduced through aquarium and water garden trade

can cause negative environmental and economic impacts (displacing native plant species, decreasing water quality, blocking hydroelectric intakes, impeding recreational activities, diminishing aesthetic value)
behavior: can grow in dense mats up to 2-3 m thick
only the female plant known to occur outside of its native range
all reproduction in its introduced range is done in the form of vegetative propagation
habitat: lakes, slow moving rivers, wetlands, riparian zones, canals, drainage ditches
prefers cool waters in areas sheltered from wind and current
grows best under high light intensity
confusion: similarity with Egeria densa, Elodea Canadensis and Hydrilla verticillata
its leaves are curved at their tips and are distinguishably alternately/spirally placed around the stem
appearance: a submerged aquatic plant
roots attach on the bottom
stem brittle, sparsely branched, up to 6 m long
leaves dark green, alternately/spirally placed around the stem, often crowded towards the apex
female flower very small, with three white/pink petals

photos.author: American Skunk Cabbage  - GBNNSS © Crown Copyright 2009
© Evelyn Simak (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.0 Generic)
© Kfediuk (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 4.0 International)
American Skunk Cabbage - © RPS group Plc

invasion: Native in Western North America
introduced in Europe through horticulture
can outcompete native mosses and orchid species
behavior: perennial plant
flowering during spring
flowers attract insects (mainly flies) due to the strong smell that is emitted
habitat: wet woodlands
grows best in nutrient rich soils
confusion: distinguishable by its bright yellow flowers
appearance: a tall herb reaching 1.5 m high
basal rosette of leathery green leaves up to 1 m long
flowers yellow, spathulate, up to 0.5 m long, enclosing one fleshy spadix
fruits are green berries at the end of the spadix

photos.author: © Ted Center (Public Domain)
Water Hyacinth - GBNNSS © Crown Copyright 2009
Water Hyacinth - GBNNSS © Crown Copyright 2009
© Wouter Hagens (Public Domain)

invasion: originates from Brazil (Amazon basin)
widely used as ornamental because of its beautiful flowers
can alter the ecosystem and result in environmental degradation and native biodiversity loss
adversely affects human activities (tourism, fishing, water transport)
behavior: spreads very rapidly
form dense mats
grows fast in eutrophicated waters
habitat: freshwater systems: lakes, wetlands, rivers and ponds
confusion: None
appearance: an aquatic floating herbaceous plant, usually up to 0.5 m high
stoloniferous roots, form dense extensive masses
leaves thick, rounded, swollen
leaf stalks bulbous, spongy
flowers on a tall spike
flowers large, purple and violet, with 6 petals, with a yellow central splotch

photos.author: Water Primrose - GBNNSS © Crown Copyright 2009
© Gergely KIRÁLY (All Rights Reserved)
© Gergely KIRÁLY (All Rights Reserved)
Water Primrose - GBNNSS © Crown Copyright 2009

invasion: native to South and Central America
introduced through aquarium trade and horticulture
outcompetes native plant species
reduces water oxygenation levels
blocks water bodies and drainage systems
impacts navigation and recreational activities
behavior: grows in varied conditions
disperses through plant fragments
forms extremely dense mats
habitat: slow-flowing freshwater habitats: streams, ponds, lakes, wetlands
confusion: very similar to Ludwigia peploides
can be distinguished by its vertically growing stems and larger flowers
appearance: emergent herbaceous aquatic plant, to 1 m high above water
early growth leaves form rosette-like clusters
leaves near flowers are lanceolate, alternate
flowers solitary, with 5 petals, stalked, bright yellow

photos.author: © Alpsdake (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)
© AndiW (public Domain)
© J. Patrick Fischer (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)
© Alpsdake (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)

invasion: native from northern parts of European Russia to central China and Korea
introduced in Europe as a pet
major reservoir for the Lyme disease agent
behavior: shelters in burrows on the ground or in cavities in trees, holes in old walls or buildings
hibernates in a burrow from October up to April
omnivorous, its diet includes both plant and animal matter
habitat: terrestrial, in suburban forests and urban parks
confusion: closely resembles the eastern chipmunk: Tamias striatus
distinguished by the arrangement of the dorsal black and white stripes
appearance: small striped squirrel, up to 25 cm long, including the tail
fur greyish-brownish
bushy greyish tail
back covered by 5 longitudinal black dorsal stripes

photos.author: © Chung Bill Bill (Creative Commons Attribution 2.0 Generic)

invasion: native in Asia, from Iraq to Myanmar, and from Pakistan to India
introduced to control rats and snakes, but proved not particularly effective
can lead to decline of native mammals, birds, reptiles, and amphibians through predation
carriers of human and animal diseases, including rabies and human Leptospira bacterium
behavior: generalist carnivore, with varied diet
seldom climbing trees
can adapt to a range of temperatures
can stand erect on hind feet supported by its muscular tail
breeds two or three times a year
habitat: terrestrial: deciduous forests, shrublands and grasslands, urban areas
prefers dry habitats
confusion: reported from the Balkans mainly as Herpestes auropunctatus, which is tentatively considered as a synonym of H. javanicus
appearance: slender long body to 70 cm long, but with short legs
fur soft, greyish to brownish
head elongated with pointed muzzle
ears short, slightly project from the fur
tail muscular, gradually tapering
paws with 5 clawed toes

photos.author: © Calibas (Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported)
© Cody Hough (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)
© Ilona Loser (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)
© Markus Krötzsch (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)

invasion: native to North America
introduced for hunting and as a pet
can outcompete other native squirrels
behavior: use leaf nests or tree cavities for shelter and litter rearing
tolerant of human proximity but not particularly playful
strictly diurnal, non-territorial
spend most of their time on the ground
impressive jumpers
excellent vision and well-developed senses of hearing and smell
habitat: open woodland, with little understory vegetation
urban areas
confusion: None
appearance: a medium-sized tree squirrel, up to 70 cm long
long foxtail-like tail
upper body brown-grey to brown-cinnamon with a typically brownish-orange underside
sharp claws

photos.author: © D. Gordon E. Robertson (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)

invasion: native in North America
introduced in Europe through accidental or deliberately aquarium releases
can result in significant shift from clear to turbid waters
can displace native fish and crayfish and reduces macroinvertebrate and macrophyte abundance and biodiversity
carriers of crayfish plague which is lethal to the native European crayfishes
behavior: highly mobile, fecund and tolerant of a wide range of environmental conditions
tends to hide in crevices under or between rocks rather than making burrows
omnivorous, consumes a variety of live and dead animal and plant material
cannot tolerate polluted waters
habitat: freshwater: streams, rivers, canals, ponds, marshes, lakes
flowing and still waters
prefers warm waters of moderate turbidity with rocky-gravel substrates
confusion: may be confused with other crayfishes, but can be distinguished by its broader, flattened tuberculate chela
appearance: crayfish to 11 cm long
carapace smooth
color reddish-brown to olive-brown
chelae broad, flattened, tuberculate, rather blue
chelae often have dark specs and orange or reddish tips

photos.author: © Jane Shelby Richardson (Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported)
© Jane Shelby Richardson (Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported)
© James H. Miller & Ted Bodner (Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported)
© James H. Miller & Ted Bodner (Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported)
© Steve Hurst (Public Domain)

invasion: native to North America
introduced into Western Europe as ornamental plant
can rapidly colonize new areas and outcompete native saltmarsh species for water and nutrients
seeds are toxic to livestock and humans
air-borne pollen is thought to be a potential allergen
behavior: a fast-growing plant
tolerate to shade and resistant to salt spray
flowering usually in early autumn
seed production very prolific with thousands seeds produced
seeds easily dispersed by wind and water
habitat: wetlands and estuaries
ditches and roadsides
confusion: sometimes confused with the bigleaf marsh-elder (Iva frutescens)
can be distinguished by its alternate leaves (contrary to the bigleaf marsh-elder)
appearance: a large fall-flowering shrub, reaching 5 m high
densely branched
leaves deciduous, simple, oval to elliptic, alternately located, usually with marginal teeth
flowers whitish, narrowly tubular, borne in numerous small crowded apical clusters
fruit one-seeded, cylindrical, subtended by white hairs called “pappus”

species.scientific_name: Pueraria montana var. lobata = Pueraria lobata

photos.author: © Doctoroftcm (Creative Commons)
© Forest & Kim Starr (Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported)
© Bastique (Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported)
©Σ64 (Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported)

invasion: native to Southeast Asia
introduced through intentional (mainly horticulture) and accidental releases
kills mostly all plants that it overgrows
a significant pest, reduces native species biodiversity and completely modifies the ecosystem
can cover and smother orchard and plantation crops causing economic damages
behavior: growth can be very rapid
can attach and climb most surfaces
seeds are dispersed by wind, animals, water
its large roots act as water reservoirs, permitting the plant to withstand drought
symbiotic relationship with nitrogen-fixing bacteria
habitat: terrestrial: forests, agricultural areas, grasslands, riparian zones
urban areas (roads, telephone poles, abandoned buildings)
confusion: None
appearance: stoloniferous and climbing perennial semi-woody vine
its large and dense roots can comprise about the half of the plant’s biomass
stems reach up to 30 m long
leaves alternate with three leaflets, pale green to greyish, usually slightly lobed
flowers purple to reddish, pea-like, commonly occurring in pairs
seed pods brown, up to 7 cm long, rather flat, hairy, and bearing 3-10 seeds

photos.author: Fanwort © RPS group Plc
Fanwort © RPS group Plc
© Leslie J. Mehrhoff, University of Connecticut (Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported)
© Leslie J. Mehrhoff, University of Connecticut (Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported)

invasion: native to subtropical temperate areas of eastern America
commonly sold as aquarium plant due to its delicate appearance
extremely persistent and competitive
decreases the biodiversity of native aquatic plants
can clog drainage canals and freshwater streams interfering with recreational, agricultural, and aesthetic uses
behavior: perennial, can survive free-floating for many weeks
forms dense crowded stands
spreads through stem fragments or rhizomes
highly tolerant of anaerobic conditions
habitat: freshwater species, grows rooted in the mud
prefers stagnant to slow flowing freshwater
prefers a warm, humid climate but can survive freezing
confusion: could be confused with similar aquatic species
can be distinguished by its flowers
appearance: an herbaceous, fully submersed aquatic plant
short fragile rhizomes grow on bottom
stems green, branched, up to 6 m long, can reach the surface
submersed leaves opposite, finely divided giving a feathery fan-like aspect
occasionally floating leaves present, blade-shaped
flowers floating, small, white to yellow or purplish

photos.author: Chinese Mitten Crab - Food and Environment Research Agency (Fera)  © Crown Copyright 2009
Chinese Mitten Crab - © Acteon.nl (All rights reserved)
Photo from www.nobanis.org, Photographer: Stephan Gollash
Photo from www.nobanis.org, Photographer: Stephan Gollash

invasion: native in the Far East
introduced through shipping and aquarium trade
can outcompete native species through predation and overlapping dietary
its burrowing activity can lead to the erosion of river banks
can damage fishing gear
intermediate host of lung flukes in East Asia
behavior: omnivorous non-discriminatory predator
feeds on various plants, invertebrates, small fishes
active migration: larvae occur in marine coastal waters and juveniles migrate upstream; adults migrate downstream to the sea for reproduction
habitat: shallow waters of rivers, lakes, estuaries
coastal marine areas
confusion: easily distinguishable by its “fur” on its claws
appearance: a rather small crab, up to 8 cm in width
brownish to greenish
characterised by a “fur” of dense mat of hairs on its claws
carapace subquadrate, markedly convex, with four acute spines on either side

photos.author: Floating Pennywort - GBNNSS  © Crown Copyright 2009
Floating Pennywort - CCW  © Crown Copyright 2009
Floating Pennywort © Snowdonia National Park Authority
Floating Pennywort © Snowdonia National Park Authority

invasion: native to North and South America
introduced in Europe through ornamental and aquarium trade
can outcompete native aquatic plants
blocks water control structures and can lead to flooding events
can create problems to boat navigation and water recreational uses
behavior: a fast growing species
forms extensive floating mats on the water surface
thrives under highly eutrophic conditions
prefers sun exposure and can resist to European winters, since its submerged parts can persist under ice cover
habitat: stagnant and slowly running water of rivers, streams, ponds, lakes, ditches
confusion: similar with other species of the genus
can be distinguished by its leaf margin which is split to central petiole, and by its overlapping marginal lobes
appearance: aquatic stoloniferous plant, floating on water
stems horizontal, bear nodes at rather regular intervals
dense mats of roots at each node as well as elongated erected stalks
leaves kidney-shaped of various sizes (2-15 cm)
flowers small, 3 mm in diameter, whitish to yellowish, borne in small clusters of 5-13
fruits brownish, ovoid-ellipsoid, strongly flattened dorsally

© Alan D. Wils (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.5 Generic)
© Derek Ramsey (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.5 Generic, 2.0 Generic and 1.0 Generic)
American Bullfrog - © Riccardo Scalera (All Rights Reserved)

invasion: native to Eastern North America
intentional introduction for cultivation and human consumption
can outcompete native amphibians
the chorusing of large males sometimes considered as noise pollution
reports of severe allergic reactions in some people who ingested bullfrogs
behavior: during metamorphosis it converts from vegetarian tadpole to carnivore that can eat any animal, even juveniles of its own species
hibernates to withstand below-freezing temperatures
only the adult males produce the frog call
habitat: freshwater systems: lakes, ponds, marshes, generally in shallow still water
prefers abundant aquatic vegetation
confusion: adult specimens very distinct but juvenile bullfrogs can easily be mistaken for other species
appearance: one of the largest frog species, reaching 18 cm long and 0.5 kg weight
olive to brownish with random dark spots on dorsal and lateral body parts, while abdominal side white
head flat with conspicuous eardrums
skin smooth
limbs with inter-digital swimming webs

photos.author: Raccoon - © Sugoto Roy
Photo from www.nobanis.org, photographer: Inger Weidema
© Bastique (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)
© Darkone (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.5 Generic)

invasion: native in Central and North America
introduced in Europe through intentional (for hunting and fur) and accidental introductions
common in the pet trade
capability of adjusting to a wide range of habitats and climatic conditions
can damage native fauna through predation and competition
susceptible to a number of diseases, such as roundworms, which can have public health consequences
behavior: mostly nocturnal
omnivore, its diet can be very diverse
excellent climbing and swimming abilities
can survive harsh winters by entering a dormant period
females remain in their natal area
habitat: almost all terrestrial habitats, but especially those adjacent to water
occasionally in urbanized areas
confusion: similar to Nyctereutes procyonoides, but the latter has 4-toed footprint (5-toed in raccoon) and does not have a ringed tail
appearance: a medium-sized mammal with characteristic black mask
fur grey, but occasionally blackish or reddish, it turns whitish on the flanks and legs
limbs rather short
tail bushy with 4-7 blackish rings

photos.author: Photo from www.nobanis.org, Photographer: Henrik Bringsøe
Photo from www.nobanis.org, Photographer: Henrik Bringsøe
Red Eared Terrapin - © Riccardo Scalera (All Rights Reserved)
Red Eared Terrapin - GBNNSS © Crown Copyright 2009

invasion: native in Eastern USA and adjacent areas
introduced in Europe through pet and food trade
very popular as a pet because of its small size and low price
can outcompete native animals, including the endangered European pond turtle Emys orbicularis
considered as a potential vector of Salmonella
large individuals can inflict painful bites to humans
behavior: an opportunistic omnivore
can live up to 20 years in the wild and 40 years in captivity
reproduction and mating may occur in spring and fal
habitat: various freshwater habitats with quiet waters and soft bottoms
prefers dense aquatic vegetation
frequently found in public ponds
confusion: None
appearance: a medium to large freshwater turtle, up to 40 cm long
prominent yellow to red patches on each side of the head
carapace and skin are olive brown with yellow stripes and spots
males are usually smaller than females and have a long, thick tail

photos.author: Water Primrose - GBNNSS © Crown Copyright 2009
© Eugene Zelenko (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 4.0 International
© Marcia Stefani (Creative Commons Attribution 2.0 Generic)

invasion: native to South America
introduced as ornamental plant in ponds and gardens
out-competes native plants
can alter the aquatic habitat by reducing oxygen levels and shading other plants
clog waterways, increasing the risk of flooding and affecting recreation, fishing and navigation
creates a breeding habitat for mosquitoes
behavior: can grow rapidly under a variety of conditions
broken fragments can grow into new plants
forms dense floating mats
flowers between July and October
vegetation dies back in winter leaving distinctive brown stems
habitat: still or slow-flowing freshwater habitats: ponds, streams, rivers, lakes, wetlands
confusion: very similar to other Ludwigia species
distinguished from Ludwigia grandiflora and L. hexapetala by its more horizontal stems and slightly smaller flowers
appearance: emergent and floating herbaceous plant
stems creeping over mud or shallow water, up to 3 m in length
leaves long, oval, resemble those of willows
leaves grow at alternating points along the stems
named for its bright yellow, primrose-like flowers, 1-3 cm in diameter
flowers have 5 petals and grow on a long stalk arising from a leaf axil

photos.author: © André Karwath aka Aka (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.5 Generic)
© André Karwath aka Aka (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.5 Generic)
Parrots Feather - GBNNSS © Crown Copyright 2009
Parrots Feather - GBNNSS © Crown Copyright 2009

invasion: native to South America
commonly sold for aquaria and aquatic gardens
outcompetes native aquatic plants
can cause water deoxygenation
impedes boats and clogs drainage ditches
provides habitat for mosquitos
behavior: prefers good light, warm and high-nutrient environments
can form dense mats
small fragments root easily in mud to establish new colonies
in Europe all plants are female
habitat: slow-moving freshwater habitats: ponds, lakes, canals
usually in muddy bottoms
confusion: the emergent small “fir trees” distinguishes it from similar species
appearance: submerged / emergent aquatic plant
stems elongate to 2 m long, suspended in the water column and/or floating
leaves finely pinnately divided, feather-like, in whorls of mostly 5
both submersed and emergent leaves, the latter resembling small “fir trees”
flowers emerge from axils of leaves

photos.author: Coypu – GBNNSS, Wildwood Trust © Crown Copyright 2009
Coypu – GBNNSS, Wildwood Trust © Crown Copyright 2009
photo from www.nobanis.org, Photographer: Bo Oelenschlaeger Madsen
photo from www.nobanis.org, Photographer: Bo Oelenschlaeger Madsen

invasion: native to South America
introduced through escapes or releases from fur farms
declines native plants through herbivory
can destroy bird nests and preys on eggs
their burrows penetrate and damage river banks, dykes and irrigation facilities
responsible for economic damages to agricultures
behavior: excellent swimmers
mainly herbivorous
fast colonizers
can breed throughout the year
severe winter can reduce reproductive success and adult survival
habitat: always near freshwater systems: rivers, lakes, marshes, drainage canals
confusion: similar to musk rat (Ondatra zibethicus), but much bigger in size and tail cylindrical (laterally flattened in musk rats)
appearance: large semi-aquatic rodent, to 6-7 kg and 1 m long including tail
rat-like appearance
pelage brown
short legs
long cylindrical tail
webbed hindfeet

photos.author: Muntjac © Norma Chapman
© Margoz (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 4.0 International, 3.0 Unported, 2.5 Generic, 2.0 Generic and 1.0 Generic)
© Karel Jakubec (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)
Muntjac - taxidermy specimen- GBNNSS © Crown Copyright 2009

invasion: native to southeast China and Taiwan
introduced deliberately for hunting or escaped from zoos
grazing can effect diversity of plant species, with indirect effects on fauna
damage horticulture
behavior: aseasonal breeders, breeding throughout the year
feed on ferns, fungi, broad-leaved trees, shrubs, nuts, fruits
basically solitary
called also the barking deer, due to its distinctive bark, though this name is also used for other deer
when disturbed they often run off in a series of springing jumps
habitat: terrestrial: deciduous woodlands, parks
confusion: None
appearance: small reddish-brown deer, to 0.5 m high (at the shoulder)
conspicuous white underside
fat tail
males with short simple antlers
facial markings: males with black frontal stripes, forming a “V”
females with a dark kite-shaped pattern on the forehead

photos.author: © Vassil (Public Domain)
© MatthiasKabel (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)
© Aga Kazmierczak (Public Domain)
© Adrian Pingstone (Public Domain)

invasion: native in South America
escaped from zoos
no ecosystem impacts are known but it could become an important predator or competitor with native species
behavior: its name ‘coati’ comes from native American Indian words meaning ‘belt’ and ‘nose’, referring to the way coatis tuck their nose into their belly while sleeping
omnivorous, eating invertebrates and fruits
males solitary, but females travel in groups of up to 30 individuals
usually active during the day, spends its nights sleeping in trees
spends much of its time foraging in trees, but can also be found on the ground
its elongated snout is very useful for searching crevices and holes for food
habitat: terrestrial: various kinds of forests and wetlands
confusion: None
appearance: similar to raccoon, up to 1 m long including tail
reddish-brown fur, whitish belly
elongated, flexible snout
white spots around its eyes
ears short and rounded
banded tail with yellow rings

photos.author: Sacred Ibis - Taxidermy specimen - GBNNSS © Crown Copyright 2009
Sacred Ibis - Taxidermy specimen - GBNNSS © Crown Copyright 2009
© Christiaan Kooyman (Public Domain)
© Johan Wessels (Creative Commons Attribution 2.0 Generic)

invasion: native to Africa
escaped from zoos
feeds on several threatened species (insects, batrachians, etc.)
feeds on eggs of several protected bird colonies
competes successfully for nest sites with native bids
suspected of spreading disease since it frequently forages in rubbish dumps and slurry pits
behavior: often forming large groups
breeds in colonies up to hundreds of pairs
carnivorous with a tendency to omnivory
feeds on insects, fishes, frogs, molluscs, crustaceans
nomadic, able to change its breeding sites to suit environmental conditions
nests often closely aggregated in trees, bushes and on ground near water
habitat: generally near water
grasslands, marshes, estuaries, farmyards, rubbish dumps, suburban areas
confusion: None
appearance: large white bird, to 90 cm long and to 120 cm wingspan
head and neck black, without feathers
long black legs
bill long, curved, black

photos.author: Signal Crayfish - GBNNSS © Crown Copyright 2009
Signal Crayfish - GBNNSS © Crown Copyright 2009
Photo from www.nobanis.org, photographer: Merike Linnamägi
Photo from www.nobanis.org, photographer: Merike Linnamägi

invasion: native in northwestern USA
used for restocking plague-devastated European crayfish
significant grazing pressure on macrophytes, aquatic insects, snails, benthic fishes and amphibian larvae
aggressive competitor to native crayfish species
threat to the native noble crayfish due to transmission of the crayfish plague fungus
behavior: high adaptability to a wide range of environments
fast-growing with high fecundity
opportunistic polytrophic feeder, consumes also detritus
constructs burrows in river and lake banks
habitat: small streams to large rivers, lakes, brackish waters
Europe so far: in almost all European countries
confusion: can be confused with the noble crayfish (Astacus astacus) but distinguished by:
the lack of spines on the shoulders of carapace
the white-turquoise patch on the claw junction
appearance: large crayfish, to 16 cm long
smooth reddish-brown exoskeleton
no spines on the shoulders of carapace
claws robust, smooth, bright red
white-turquoise patch on the claw junction

photos.author: Red Swamp Crayfish © Trevor Renals
Red Swamp Crayfish © Trevor Renals

invasion: native to north-eastern Mexico and south-central USA
intentional introduced for aquaculture, but can spread also by anglers for local consumption, and as bait
widely available in the aquarium trade
outcompetes the native European crayfish (family Astacidae) through transmission of the crayfish fungus plague Aphanomyces astaci
degrades riverbanks because of its burrowing activity
accumulates heavy metals and toxins produced by Cyanobacteria, and can transfer them to its consumers, including humans
behavior: tolerant to a wide range of environmental conditions
benthic and omnivorous, feeding on insects, larvae, detritus, etc., with a preference for animal matter
burrows during periods of drought or cold
tolerates dry periods of up to 4 months
exhibits territorial behaviour and is aggressive with its own species
habitat: prefers small but permanent freshwater systems: swamps, ditches, sloughs, ponds
avoids streams with a strong flow
confusion: None
appearance: crayfish to 12 cm long
body shape cylindrical
conspicuously granular carapace with marginal spines
adults dark red, orange, or reddish brown
chelae narrow and long, with bright red tubercles and spines
sexually active males with distinct grasping hooks on the ischia, used to hold females during copulation

photos.author: © Astacoides (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)
© Andreas R. Thomsen (public domain)
© A.Berger (Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported)
Orconectes limosus © Francesca Pilotto
Orconectes limosus © Francesca Pilotto
Orconectes limosus © Francesca Pilotto
Orconectes limosus © Francesca Pilotto
Orconectes limosus © Francesca Pilotto

invasion: native to North America
originally introduced into Europe to replace diminished populations of the Signal crayfish
escaped also from aquaria or introduced as fish bait
can outcompete native crayfish species
carrier of the crayfish plague
its burrows may destabilize river banks
behavior: tolerant of a wide range of environmental conditions
omnivore
high fecundity and rapid reproduction
able to cope with polluted canals and lakes
benthic, able to dig burrows and lie dormant when water levels fall and conditions are unfavourable
habitat: freshwater: rivers, wide steams, ponds, lakes
prefers calm and turbid waters to fast flowing
prefers flat, sandy, rocky floors
confusion: none
appearance: small to medium-sized crayfish, up to 10 cm long
distinctive spiny cheeks
legs with orange tips and striped abdomens, but are often coloured black from the sediment they live in

invasion: native to Asia: Russia, China, North Korea
commonly kept in aquaria and used as live bait
exhaust the entire food supplies, and can outcompete native species for the same food resources
can have an adverse overall impact on native aquatic fauna
behavior: can tolerate poorly oxygenated water
able to survive in dried out or completely frozen water bodies by digging itself into mud where it hibernates
voracious predator, feeds on wide variety of invertebrates, tadpoles and fish
males guard the eggs and pelagic larvae
habitat: freshwater fish: lakes, ponds, marshes, rivers
prefers stagnant rivers with dense underwater vegetation and muddy substrate
confusion: can be distinguished from other similar freshwater fishes by its two dorsal fins: the first with 6-8 simple rays, the second with 2-3 simple and 8-12 branched rays
appearance: a freshwater small/medium fish up to 25 cm long
robust scaled body
coloration rather dark; varies from greenish-olive to brownish-grey depending on substrate
on the dorsal and lateral sides there are dark irregular spots and blotches
large mouth with caniform teeth
two dorsal fins: the first with 6-8 simple rays, the second with 2-3 simple and 8-12 branched rays
males during spawning period become black with bright green spots on body

photos.author: Marbled crayfish- Cefas © Crown Copyright 2009

invasion: native in North America
one of the most widely distributed crayfish species in the international pet trade
introduced after pet aquaria releases
threatens native crayfish due to competition and transmission of the crayfish plague
may have significant impact on fish populations
behavior: only females exist which lay unfertilized eggs that develop into genetically uniform offspring (parthenogenesis)
high reproductive potential: one single specimen is sufficient to create a new population
no males have ever been recorded
fast growing species
lives in open water during most of its life and burrows only under extreme conditions
polytrophic omnivore
habitat: freshwater: rivers, lakes, swamps, drainage ditches, fish ponds
confusion: distinguished from other crayfish species by the color pattern (a marble pattern with dark lateral horizontal stripes through the carapace and pleon)
appearance: medium-sized crayfish up to 10 cm long
distinct, appealing marbled color pattern
dark lateral horizontal stripes through the carapace
dorsal carapace smooth, but lateral surface slightly granulated
acute cervical spine present at each side and the cephalic section, bearing tubercles
chelae relatively small, being two times shorter than the carapace length

invasion: native in East Asian, including Japan and parts of Korea and China
introduced in Europe with stocking material of herbivorous fishes imported from China
feeds on juvenile stages of many locally valuable native fish species
vector of infectious diseases threatening both native and farmed fish in Europe
probably contributed to a decrease in abundance of some native cyprinids
behavior: zooplanktivorous
able for rapid expansion
saline intolerant, not occurring in brackish waters
males guard the eggs until hatching, and aggressively drive away other fish
habitat: freshwater systems: shallow lakes, carp ponds, irrigation canals, ditches
confusion: None
appearance: small fish, up to 11 cm long
color: back grey, light sides, yellowish-green to silver belly
elongated body, slightly flattened on sides
head flattened in its anterior part
mouth clearly in top position
lateral line complete, running in the middle of sides

invasion: native to the Indian subcontinent
deliberately introduced for cleaning refuse from towns
unintentional introductions associated with increased global sea traffic and trade
poses a risk to native avifauna
food/crop theft
noise nuisance
possibly acting as carrier of human and animal disease
behavior: generalist, opportunistic
intelligent, very gregarious and aggressive, have little fear of man
nests mainly in large trees
monogamous, pair for life
omnivorous, feeding on fruits, birds, mammals, reptiles and garbage
noisy birds, typically emitting a rather flat and nasal sounding “kaaa-kaaa”
habitat: always near human settlements
no populations are known to live independently of humans
moves into surrounding farmlands and seashores to forage
confusion: distinguished from other craws by differences in eye color, body shape and calls
appearance: slender, medium-sized crow, to 40 cm long
relatively long legs and large bill
glossy black except for a well-defined smoky-grey 'collar', from hindcrown to mantle and breast, the shade of which can vary
bill and legs black, eyes black-brown
tail black, fairly long with rounded end

invasion: native to North and South America
accidentally introduced
replaces native flora due to allelopathy
severe economic damages to crops
consumption by livestock can taint meat
pollen contains allergens that can cause reactions such as dermatitis and hay fever
behavior: aromatic, annual
drought tolerate
high seed production
seeds small and light, spread by water, animals, vehicles, machinery
aggressive colonizer of disturbed ground
habitat: terrestrial plant, grows in any type of soil
prolific in disturbed habitats: roadsides, railway tracks, rivers, creek banks
also in villages, gardens, plant nurseries, crop fields
confusion: may be confused with ragweeds (Ambrosia spp.), but can be distinguished by the alternate leaves and white flowers
appearance: annual, erect herb to 1.5 m high, with a deep taproot and basal rosette
much branched
stem rigid, becomes woody with age
leaves pale green, deeply lobed, alternate on the stem
leaves and stem covered by soft hairs
flowers small, white, borne in branched terminal panicles
seeds black, flattened, 2mm long with two thin, white scales

invasion: native in eastern Asia
unintentionally introduced in America via rhododendron nursery stock
can smother native vegetation and climb into the tree canopy where it restricts light availability to plants below
can be a pest plant on tree farms and horticultural crops
used in Chinese medicine
behavior: climbing over shrubs and trees
annual
fast growing
seeds spread through animals
seeds also buoyant, can be spread by streams and floods
habitat: terrestrial, common in forest edges, wetlands, stream banks and roadsides
prefers moist areas, but can also grow on dry land
confusion: similar to other vine species, but distinguished by the presence of spines and ocrea
appearance: herbaceous scrambling vine, to 6 m high
delicate, highly branched reddish stems
stems covered by small curved spines
leaves alternate, triangular, light green
round leaf-like structures called ocrea surround the stem at intervals
inconspicuous small white flowers arise from ocrea
fruits green, turning blue when matured, arranged in clusters

invasion: native in Southeast Asia
introduced in France through boxes of pottery from China
highly aggressive predator of native honey bees
could be dangerous for man by inducing a life-threatening allergic reaction or after multiple stings, similar to the native hornet stings
behavior: hunts honey bees and other insects
active in April-November
makes very large nests, to 75 cm long, in tall trees in urban and rural areas
only one mated queen is enough to start a new colony and initiate further spread
ability to thermoregulate their nests to a constant temperature of around 30°C
vigorously defends its hunting territory, chasing off any rivals
habitat: the paper nests are usually built in tree canopies, or occasionally in buildings, and very rarely near the ground
confusion: distinguished by the European hornet by its smaller size, the characteristic yellow legs, and the dark abdomen with only one yellow band
never active at night whereas European hornets may be
appearance: dark brown velvety body
characteristically dark abdomen with a distinctive yellow band on the fourth segment
head black and face yellow
yellow tipped legs
smaller than the native European hornet, workers to 2 cm long

invasion: native to Africa
introduced as ornamental to zoos and gardens
competes with native birds for food and nesting sites
grazing on native flora
may cause agricultural damages
behavior: good swimmer
vocalisations of the sexes differ
eats seeds, leaves, grasses, plant stems
annual migrations
aggressively territorial
usually pairs for life
habitat: wetland habitats: lakes, ponds, estuaries, swamps
grasslands
urban parks
confusion: can be easily distinguished by the long pink legs and brown patches around the eyes and neck
appearance: pale brown plumage
long pink legs
pinkish bill
brown patches around the eyes
brown neckline
male and female do not differ

invasion: native to South America
introduced in Europe as a contaminant in bird seeds and bonsai plants
can blanket the water surface, impede light penetration, promote sedimentation and flooding
in terrestrial habitats it degrades riverbanks, pastures, and agricultural lands, producing massive underground root systems
provides habitat for mosquitoes and degrades natural aesthetics
affects agriculture, irrigation and fisheries
behavior: perennial
grows vigorously
spreads through floating fragments
dense mats in shallow slow-moving water bodies
stems lose many leaves and become prostrate in winter
flowering from mid to late summer
habitat: amphibious, in both terrestrial and aquatic habitats
forests, riparian systems and wetlands
agricultural lands, disturbed areas and urban habitats
confusion: the water primroses (Ludwigia species) are similar, but the latter are distinguished by their alternately arranged leaves and larger 4-petalled flowers
appearance: amphibious emergent stoloniferous grass
simple or branched stems, hollow when aquatic, up to 10 m long
can form thick interwoven mats throughout the water body
leaves dark green, elliptic, glabrous, lanceolate and opposite
flowers white, terminal, small, on a short stalk

invasion: native to North America
introduced into Europe as ornamental and for beekeeping
highly invasive (competitive) and persistent weed, threatens native species
negative economic impacts in agriculture
can be poisonous to sheep, cattle, poultry, even to humans
potential vector of fungal and virus plant diseases
behavior: perennial
flowers produce copious amounts of nectar
flowering usually from June to August
grows usually as a colony of plants
many kinds of insects visit its flowers for pollination
habitat: woodlands, grasslands, marshlands
sandy soils, prefers sunny areas
common to roadsides, railway areas, wastelands, abandoned orchards, vineyards
confusion: similar to Asclepias speciosa but the latter has broader, oval and rounded leaves and densely woolly stalks
similar to Asclepias tuberosa but the latter has orange flowers
similar to Apocynum cannabinum but the latter has narrow, elliptical leaves, not hairy
appearance: herbaceous, up to 2 m tall
long-spreading rhizomes
stems stout, with white latex (sticky milky sap)
leaves opposite, oblong, with prominent veins
leaves’ upper surface smooth, lower covered with short white hairs
flowers fragrant, nectariferous, pink to white, in umbellate clusters

invasion: native to North America
introduced into Europe as an aquarium plant
can form dense submerged beds
can outcompete native plants
blocks pipes and drainage systems
impedes boating, fishing and affects recreation activities
behavior: perennial
rapid growth
fragments easily dispersed by currents, attached to machinery, footwear, fishing equipment
tolerant to disturbance such as oil pollution
stimulated by fertilization with nitrogen
habitat: still waters such as shorelines of lakes, reservoirs, ponds, along rivers and streams, wetlands, canals, ditches
able to grow in turbid, highly eutrophic waters as well as in clear waters
generally shallow water, 3 to 5 m depth
confusion: smaller, paler, leaves shorter and narrower than Elodea canadensis
similar to Egeria densa but the latter has longer leaves in whorls of 4–6
similar to Lagarosiphon major, but the latter has very strongly recurved leaves and in spirals whereas those of E. nuttallii are in whorls
appearance: submerged aquatic plant
rooting at nodes
stems long and slender, often freely branched
leaves pale green, typically in whorls of 3, lanceolate, often recurved with folded margins
floating flowers, white, at the tips of long stalks

invasion: native to South America
introduced into Europe as ornamental
shades out native flora
erosion to river banks
can alter natural successional processes and change vegetation structure
can block drain and streams, enhancing flooding
behavior: perennial
forms dense colonies
flowers from spring to early summer
deciduous, leaves die in autumn
rhizomes’ fragments have the potential to form new plants
habitat: habitats with moderate to heavy rainfall and frost-free conditions
coastal cliffs, stream and river banks, lake and pond margins
common in  roadsides, damps and disturbed habitats
confusion: very similar to Gunnera manicata
the inflorescences are rather open in Gunnera manicata and closed in Gunnera tinctoria (club-like)
appearance: large herbaceous broadleaved plant, up to 2 m high
very large leaves, up to 2 m wide, hairy in the lower page
leaves’ stalks have reddish bristles and spines
flowers large, cone-shaped, borne on panicles up to 1 m tall
massive over-wintering buds on the rhizomes, covered by pinkish scales

invasion: native to Caucasus
introduced into Europe as ornamental
competes and replaces most native plants
soil erosion
serious dermatological effects on skin (avoid touching it)
behavior: perennial
forms monospecific stands
prolific seed production
flowers only once, when 3-5 years old
flowering from June to August
once it has flowered, the plant dies
habitat: well-lit, nutrient rich and moist soils
common along roadsides, river banks, railways, woodland fringes, grasslands
ruderal sites such as rubbish dumps and waste grounds
confusion: very similar to Heracleum sphondylium and H. montanum, but these are usually smaller (< 2 m high)
H. persicum is also smaller, with leaves more elongate
H. sosnowskyi is more densely hairy with umbel rays finely scabrous-hairy
appearance: large broadleaved plant, up to 4-5 m high
stems often purple spotted
leaves alternate, pinnately lobed, up to 3 m long
upper leaf surface glabrous, the underside covered by bristles
flowers white or pinkish, clustered in a terminal umbrella-shaped head (umbel), up to 80 cm in diameter
each umbel with 30-150 hairy rays

invasion: native to Himalaya
introduced in Europe as ornamental
may reduce native species diversity
can exclude native plants from pollination
facilitates river bank erosion
behavior: annual, present in spring-summer
rapid growth
forms dense stands
exclusively seed propagated
the flowers have the highest sugar nectar production in Europe
attracts numerous insect pollinators, especially bees
habitat: moist and relatively nutrient rich habitats
riparian systems, river banks, woodlands
common in railways, waste grounds, urban areas, roadside ditches

appearance: erect plant up to 3 m high
stems reddish, branched, hollow, hairless

inflorescences in groups of 2-14 flowers

invasion: native to Asia
seeds spread as contaminants on shoes, clothes, machinery, soil
outcompetes native plants
can alter soil properties
may decrease arthropod abundance and diversity
used in the past as packing material for porcelain
behavior: annual
seed propagated
shade tolerant
rapid growth
may form dense monospecific stands
flowering and fruiting in late summer
habitat: riparian habitats, wetlands
shaded understoreys of forest margins
variety of disturbed sites: roadsides, railroads, ditches, damp fields

appearance: decumbent delicate grass
pale green in color but during fall turns to pale-purple
leaves alternate, lanceolate, with pointed apex
a silvery line runs down the middle of the upper leaf surface
multiple flowers grouped in racemes, terminal or arising from the leaf axils

invasion: native to southeast USA
introduced through aquarium trade
outcompetes native aquatic plants
the weed mats prevent water flow, reduce sunlight and oxygen availability
impedes swimming, boating and fishing
negatively impacts drainage and irrigation systems, hydropower and drinking water resources
behavior: perennial
forms dense mats
spreads primarily via fragmentation
flowering rare, from May to October
can tolerate hot summer as well as cold winter temperatures
habitat: lakes, ponds, rivers, swamps, mudflats, wetlands, irrigation channels
standing and slow flowing waters
up to 4 m water depth
confusion: very similar to other Myriophyllum species, distinguished by characters of flowers and fruits
can be recognized by the undivided, serrate emergent leaves when present

stems stout, dark red to brown, up to 1 m long

invasion: native to North America
introduced into Europe for fur farming
damages vegetation through grazing
may threaten invertebrate communities
burrowing can weaken riverbanks causing them to collapse
damage to agriculture, railways, dams, dikes, fish farms
could host parasites affecting humans and domestic animals
behavior: territorial
fast growing with high rate of reproduction
well adapted for swimming, spends most of its time in water
can create two types of habitation: burrows in river banks or lodges
mainly nocturnal
essentially herbivorous, sometimes omnivorous
habitat: riverbanks with slow moving waters
lakes, ponds and wetlands
estuaries and brackish habitats
confusion: distinct from nutria (Myocastor coypus) by its flattened and hairless tail (rounded and hairy in nutria)
appearance: large amphibious rodent, 40-70 cm long
broad head and short rounded ears
fur from grey to brown, with underside slightly paler
fur dense and waterproof

can cause riverbank erosion
toxic to humans; skin burning after physical contact

perennial
flowers during summer

invasion: native in North and Central America
introduced in Europe by escapes and accidental releases from breeding farms
poses a threat to the endangered white-headed duck (Oxyura leucocephala) through hybridization and competition
behavior: excellent divers
omnivorous, feeding on small invertebrates, seeds and parts of aquatic plants

seasonal dispersal in resident UK populations
habitat: shallow pools, marshes, lakes
sometimes in sheltered coastal areas
prefers dense aquatic vegetation
confusion: None

invasion: originating from south-eastern Siberia
introduced for hunting and fur
high capability to spread to new areas, it may also spread to northern areas due to global warming
suspected for predation of native birds and frogs
important vector of rabies and parasites
behavior: excellent swimmer
nocturnal
omnivorous
high reproductive potential
monogamous, the male participates in warming and guarding the pups when the female is foraging
can hibernate in areas where winters are harsh
habitat: open landscapes, especially damp meadows with abundant undergrowth
marshes, lake and river shores
small forests with abundant berries
can visit gardens searching for fruits and berries
confusion: The facial mask resembles that of the raccoon (Procyon lotor), they can be easily distinguished by the raccoon’s striped tail. Carcasses tracks of roadkill animals  can be confused with those of badgers (Meles meles).
appearance: black facial mask
small rounded ears
body color varies from yellow to grey or reddish
black hairs on the back, shoulders and dorsally on the tail
legs, feet and chest dark
short tail covered with thick hair
